title-group.article-title: Adhesive Strips for the Closure of Surgical Incisional Sites
title-group.subtitle: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis

article-meta.aff: 1Alfa Institute of Biomedical Sciences (AIBS), Athens, Greece
4Athens University School of Medicine, Athens, Greece
5Tufts University School of Medicine, Boston, MA, USA

author-notes.corresp: Matthew E. Falagas, Alfa Institute of Biomedical Sciences (AIBS), 9 Neapoleos Street, 151 23 Marousi, Athens, Greece Email: m.falagas@aibs.gr

abstract.p: Background. The authors evaluated the available evidence regarding the use of adhesive strips for the management of surgical incisions and compared them with sutures and other closure materials. Study design. Systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials (RCTs). Results. Twelve RCTs studying 1317 incisions in 1023 patients were included. No difference was found regarding the development of infection (odds ratio [OR] = 0.47; 95% Confidence interval [CI] = 0.12-1.85), dehiscence (OR = 1.22; 95% CI = 0.32-4.64), and overall cosmetic result (standardized mean difference = 0.01; 95% CI = −0.19 to 0.20). Closure with strips resulted in significantly lower incidence of redness (OR = 0.57; 95% CI = 0.37-0.89). The available data on pain, need for resuturing, swelling, patient satisfaction, and closure time with the use of strips could not be synthesized; however, regarding the latter 2 outcomes, application of strips seemed favorable. There was significant heterogeneity among the studies. Conclusions. The findings suggest that adhesive strips may be an efficient closure material for certain small-length incisions. Further research is warranted on outcomes such as dehiscence and the need for resuturing.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Adhesive strips have been used in the management of surgical wounds during the past 50 years.1 Still, no specific indications exist for their use. In practice, strips are most commonly used to manage simple traumatic laceration, achieve early suture or staple removal, and support or reinforce loosely sutured wounds.2 Strips’ manufacturers advertise that their product is quite close to the definition of the ideal wound closure method; rapid, inexpensive, painless, limiting the chance of infection, and with optimal cosmetic results.3,4

Wound healing can be affected by various factors, both systemic and local.5 Systemic factors predisposing to impaired healing include increased age,6 decreased estrogens, and increased androgens (particularly in the elderly),7 stress,8 diabetes mellitus,9 obesity,10 smoking,11 alcohol consumption,12 and impaired nutrition.13 Local factors affecting wound healing include tissue oxygenation (which may be different in the various parts of the body)14 and wound infection.15

Theoretically, sutureless skin closure may have certain advantages such as equal skin tension in the entire length of the incision, noninvasive application, and a gentler handling of tissues that may prevent scaring and necrosis. On the other hand, some surgeons are reluctant to use adhesive strips, claiming that wounds closed with strips are more prone to dehiscence, especially when referring to major surgical incisions and wounds with tension at highly contoured areas and/or areas of musculoskeletal movement.

Thus, sutures and staples remain the standard method of surgical incision closure since the advent of aseptic surgery enabled a safe and reliable method of suturing wounds.16-19 The use of surgical tape in the management of superficial incisions still remains unclear. We sought to perform a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials (RCTs) examining the use of adhesive strips for surgical incisional site closure and comparing them with sutures and other closure materials.

sec.title: Data Sources
sec.p: To identify relevant RCTs, we systematically searched PubMed, Scopus, and Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials with the following keywords: “adhesive strip” or “adhesive tape” and “wound closure” for PubMed and Scopus and “adhesive strip” and “wound closure” and “infection” or “complications” for Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials. The search was done on July 11, 2010. Moreover, we reviewed the references of the included RCTs to identify further evidence. Abstracts from conferences or unpublished studies were not sought.

sec.title: Study Selection
sec.p: One investigator (IDG) performed literature search to identify potentially eligible studies. Any RCT comparing adhesive strips to any other method of closure of superficial traumatic wounds or surgical incisional sites was considered eligible for inclusion. No restriction was set regarding language. Time of publication was restricted from 1990 onward. Finally, we excluded studies in pediatric populations.

sec.title: Data Extraction
sec.p: The data extraction was independently performed by 2 investigators (IDG and MNM). Any disagreement was resolved by consensus. The following data was extracted from all eligible articles: study design, year of publication, study population, surgical procedure, closure methods, wound or incision characteristics, closure time, development of wound infection, patients’ satisfaction, pain on closure method application and on removal of the closure material, cosmesis, and other complications.

Wound closure was defined as the skin edge approximation of surgical incisional sites. All incisional sites presenting superficial infection, as reported by the authors of the studies, were considered infected. Cosmesis data were extracted only if there was a valid cosmetic score and/or assessment by an independent evaluator. Wound dehiscence was defined as the reopening of the incisional site after the wound closure, without the need for secondary closure. In addition, the following components were individually assessed according to the Jadad score for RCTs20: randomization, blinding, and reporting of withdrawals. Studies with a score greater than 2 were considered of adequate quality.21,22

sec.title: Data Analysis and Statistical Methods
sec.p: Statistical analyses were performed using Review Manager (RevMan) V.5.0 Software (The Nordice Cochrane Centre, The Cochrane Collaboration, Copenhagen, 2008). The χ2 test and I2 were used to assess statistical heterogeneity among the included studies; a P value <.10 was defined to note statistical heterogeneity. Continuous variables were assessed using weighted mean difference (WMD) or standardized mean difference (SMD) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs), whereas for the assessment of dichotomous variables, pooled odds ratios (ORs) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) were calculated. Fixed effect model or DerSimonian random effects model was used based on heterogeneity testing. The OpenEpi Software was used to calculate P values for pain assessment and patients’ satisfaction where appropriate.23

sec.title: Selected Studies
sec.p: We initially retrieved 330 articles from our primary search. A total of 18 articles were RCTs examining our hypothesis (Figure 1). After excluding old studies (published before 1990) and those enrolling pediatric patients, a total of 12 studies were included in this meta-analysis.24-35

caption.p: Flow diagram of the reviewed studies (RCTs = randomized controlled trials)

sec.title: Characteristics of the Included Studies
sec.p: The main characteristics of the included are presented in Table 1. A total of 1317 incisional sites in 1023 patients had been reported. The sample size of the studies ranged from 26 to 250 patients (and surgical incisional sites). Adhesive strips, sutures, and tissue adhesive glue were used to close 559, 641, and 127 incisions, respectively. Six studies compared adhesive strips with sutures,25,26,29,31,32,35 3 adhesive strips with sutures and tissue adhesive,24,30,33 1 adhesive strips with sutures and staples,28 1 adhesive strips with sutures and simple sterile dressing,34 and 1 study compared adhesive strips with sutures with tissue adhesive.27 The follow-up period ranged from 3 days to 12 months. Out of the 12 studies, 9 did not report any funding or conflict of interest.24,28-35 None of the reviewed studies mentioned the degree of contamination of the surgical sites.

caption.p: Characteristics of the Studies Included in the Meta-Analysis

fn.p: Abbreviations: NR, not reported; F, female; M, male; po, postoperative; ITT, intention to treat; SD, standard deviation; VATS, video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery; HRT, hormone replacement therapy.

sec.p: All studies reported on surgical incisional sites (no eligible study examined traumatic lacerations). Five studies reported on adhesive strips versus other methods for closure of port sites in laparoscopic and arthroscopic operations.24,29,30,32,34 Closure of incisions in limbs were reported in 3 studies.26,28,33 Vascular harvest sites were examined in 2 studies,27,35 whereas surgical incisional sites on thorax were reported in 3 studies,25,26,35 and in the abdomen in 1 study.25 All the available studies reported on closing of small incisions. There was no direct comparison of strips’ performance for the closure of different incisional sites. None of the articles studied the outcomes of combined closure of skin with sutures and strips.

sec.title: Pain
sec.p: Five studies evaluated pain post–incisional site closure.27,29,32,34,35 There was considerable heterogeneity among the included studies regarding the scales and methods used for pain evaluation; 2 studies used the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) score,29,34 whereas a 10-point scale and a 4-point scale were used in 2 studies,32,35 and 1 study,27 respectively (Table 2). No study reported significant difference between the compared groups regarding pain perception on follow-up. In addition, data regarding the need for analgesic treatment (pain medications with or without opiates) were provided in 1 study29; significantly more analgesia was required in the sutures group.

caption.p: Data Extracted From the Included Randomized Controlled Trials Regarding Outcomes of the Meta-Analysis

fn.p: Measured in seconds per incision, unless otherwise stated.

fn.p: Calculated by dividing the time taken to close the wound (in seconds) by the total length of incision to be closed (in millimeters).

fn.p: Subcuticular sutures, over all 5 days of postoperative follow-up, were causing the least amount of pain (P < .05).

fn.p: In the strips and simple dressing group, all patients were very satisfied, whereas 5/63 (8%) patients in the suture group were unhappy with the wound cosmesis.

fn.p: The median suture time was 127 seconds longer than that of strips (P = .007).

fn.label: g
fn.p: Referred to the number of surgical incisional sites.

sec.title: Closure time
sec.p: Two of the included studies reported on time needed to close the incisional site.24,25 In both studies, application of strips was faster compared with sutures.

sec.title: Infection
sec.p: Eight studies provided data regarding the development of wound infection.24,26-30,34,35 There was no significant difference between strips and sutures (OR = 0.47; 95% CI = 0.12-1.85; 542 incisions, Figure 2). The 2 studies that compared strips with tissue adhesive for development of infection did not notice any significant difference.

caption.p: Comparison of development of wound infection: Strips versus sutures

Vertical line indicates no difference between the compared groups. Diamond shapes indicate pooled odds ratios (95% confidence intervals [CIs]). Horizontal lines indicate 95% CIs. Squares indicate point estimates; the size of the squares indicates the weight that each study has in the meta-analysis.

sec.title: Cosmesis
sec.p: Nine studies provided data on the cosmetic evaluation of the wounds (Table 2).25-28,30,31,33-35 Two used the VAS score,30,35 whereas a 4-point scale and a 9-point scale were used in 3 studies,26,27,35 and 2 studies,31,33 respectively (one did not specify).34 Cosmesis was evaluated using verbal scales in 1 study.28 Five of the studies reported statistically significant differences between the compared groups on follow-up.25-27,30,35 Only 5 studies provided data eligible for statistical synthesis. We preferably used standardized scores reported by surgeons, in the latest follow-up point, no later than 1 year postoperatively. There was no difference in the cosmetic result; the pooled SMD was 0.01, 95% CI = −0.19 to 0.20 (414 incisions, Figure 3).

caption.p: Comparison of the overall cosmetic result, as assessed by a physician (preferably a surgeon): Strips versus sutures

Vertical line indicates no difference between the compared groups. Diamond shapes indicate pooled odds ratios (95% confidence intervals [CIs]). Horizontal lines indicate 95% CIs. Squares indicate point estimates. The size of the squares is indicative of the weight that each study has in the meta-analysis.

sec.title: Other complications
sec.p: Considerable heterogeneity was noted regarding the complications reported by different studies (Table 2). There was no significant difference in wound dehiscence (OR = 1.22; 95% CI = 0.32-4.64, 235 incisions, Figure 4). Only one study examined the need for resuturing24; there was a statistically significant difference in favor of sutures. Postclosure redness was significantly higher in the sutures group (OR = 0.57; 95% CI = 0.37-0.89, 376 incisions, Figure 4). Finally, swelling was studied by 3 of the included trials (the data were not eligible for meta-analysis)27,32,34; 2 noticed significantly higher rates of wound swelling in the sutures group,27,34 whereas the third did not notice any difference.32

caption.p: Comparison of development of other wound complications: Strips versus sutures

Vertical line indicates no difference between the compared groups. Diamond shapes indicate pooled odds ratios (95% confidence intervals [CIs]). Horizontal lines indicate 95% CIs. Squares indicate point estimates; the size of the squares indicates the weight that each study has in the meta-analysis.

sec.title: Patient satisfaction
sec.p: Patient satisfaction was evaluated in 6 of the included studies.25,26,30,31,33,35 A VAS score scale, a 4-point scale, a 5-point scale, and a 9-point scale were used in 1,30 2,26,35 2,31,33 and 1 study,25 respectively. Two studies reported that strips were associated with a significantly higher patient satisfaction on follow-up (Table 2).26,31

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Our findings suggest that development of wound infection, pain, dehiscence, and cosmesis did not differ significantly in the adhesive strips group compared with other closure methods (sutures, staples, and tissue glue). The application of strips was associated with lower incidence of redness; it also appeared to be faster and lead to higher patient satisfaction, although relevant data were reported in only 2 studies.

Only one study examined the need for resuturing32 and found it significantly higher for wounds closed with strips. Although data derived from only one study cannot allow for safe conclusions, this may be explained by the fact that accurate skin edge apposition is not always possible because of the eversion of the skin edges caused by the reduction of postoperative swelling. On the other hand, 3 studies reported on the dehiscence rates; there was no significant difference in dehiscence risk when strips were compared to suturing, stapling, and tissue glue.25,28,33 Further research is needed to examine the rates of dehiscence and need for resuturing that may be attributed to strips among various populations and types of wounds.

There was significant heterogeneity in the methods used to evaluate pain and patient’s satisfaction. Thus, a meta-analysis on these outcomes could not be performed. Of importance, 5 studies reported that pain was significantly lower when strips were used (in comparison with sutures).27,29,32,34,35

Fast application and no need of local anaesthesia make adhesive strips ideal for use in the emergency care and paediatrics. On the other hand, there are certain requirements for the proper application of strips; “dry skin, reasonably strict haemostasis, accurate apposition of edges, the use of an adhesive adjunct (benzoin), and application so that skin tension is distributed along the entire tape.”36 Highly contoured surface, such as the axilla, may make adhesive strips application insufficient.28 Last, hair restricts certain body areas from strip use.

In theory, adhesive strips may cause less tissue damage as they involve the epidermis rather than the dermis that is strangulated when suturing. Moreover, the deposition of wound collagen that happens during suturing is related to reduced wound oxygenation and perfusion.37 Strips are also claimed to have an almost painless removal and to not result in cross-hatching scars. On the other hand, poor suturing technique may result in insufficient cosmesis. Even though the VAS has been shown to be a valid measure for the evaluation of cosmesis, evaluator’s subjectivity is a main turnover of cosmetic assessment.38 In addition, the variety of measurement scales, on the aesthetic result of wound healing and on pain, induced notable heterogeneity. On these grounds, we found no difference on the cosmetic outcome when we compared adhesive strips and sutures.

Adhesive strips do not seem to favor bacterial growth. However, the use of adhesive adjuncts may stimulate the host’s response to infection.39,40 The development of wound infection may be influenced by the location as well as the nature of the surgical operation. Patient’s skin flora is the main source of pathogens involved in the majority of superficial surgical infections.41 Various factors, such as age, obesity, diabetes, nutritional status, and smoking influence the normal skin flora.41-43 A potential immune deficiency, a preexistent or coexistent infection at a specific body site, and the duration of preoperative hospital stay can also be factors that modify the skin flora.41 The results of this meta-analysis provide evidence that, regarding postclosure wound infection, the use of strips did not differ significantly from the standard techniques of suturing, stapling, and applying tissue glue.

Various studies mention the economic aspect of adhesive strips in the treatment of surgical incisional sites. One study calculated that the cost per package of sutures was almost twice the cost per package of strips (€2.47 vs €1.15).30 Another study reported that strips cost less (20% as much as sutures and 12.5% that of tissue adhesives), thereby reducing the overall cost of medical care.44 According to the same study, adhesive strips had the lowest average cost per laceration ($7.54), the lowest cost per infected laceration ($53.40) and the lowest cost per laceration with dehiscence ($25.40). The relative cost for sutures was $24.11, $69.91, and $41.91, respectively, and the cost for tissue adhesives was $28.77, $74.68, and $46.68, respectively.44 Moreover, the reduction of the operative time required for superficial wound closure has an indirect impact on the total operative costs; 1 minute less in the operating room might save the patient $64.20 to $75.30.

Several limitations should be considered when interpreting the findings of this study. First, trials assessing wound closure have a significant methodological limitation; blinding of both the patient and the surgeon is impossible based on the compared interventions. Moreover, we observed significant heterogeneity regarding pain measurement scales and patient satisfaction. The subjectivity that characterizes perception of pain and patient’s satisfaction restrained our efforts to reach conclusive results. The quality of the included studies presents another limitation; 9 out of 12 studies were of poor quality (as defined by the modified Jadad score). Furthermore, the use of different types of adhesive strips, sutures, and techniques in suturing, as well as the variance of surgical skills may have influenced our findings. Last, certain confounding factors such as wound location, local skin flora, and patient age on wound cicatrization may have also affected our findings.

Although our meta-analysis included a total of 12 original studies, data synthesized for individual outcomes were extracted from considerably fewer studies (ie, 3 studies for wound dehiscence and redness). In addition, there was significant variance in the outcomes that each study reported. This highlights the need for a common way to look at outcomes in this field. Specifically, future studies evaluating the effectiveness of adhesive strips (or other methods of wound closure) should report on the dehiscence rates and the need for resuturing, as well as other outcomes, such as wound infection, and closure time.

In conclusion, our meta-analysis provides evidence that the use of adhesive strips may be faster than, and as safe as sutures, staples and adhesive glue for the management of certain small length lacerations and incisions. Strips were also associated with lower incidence of wound redness. However, available evidence on clinically important outcomes, such as wound dehiscence and need for resuturing, is not sufficient to draw any safe conclusions. Additional studies on the use of adhesive strips, focusing on the rate of dehiscence and resuturing with regard to the extent (depth, width, and shape) and the location of the incision, would be of additional value.

ack.p: We would like to acknowledge the kind contribution of Ioannis Mamais to the statistical analysis of this study.

fn.p: The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
The author(s) received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
